PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (16:58): by leave—I present the following 55 petitions:
Native Title: Western Australia

We note that is nearly three decades since Native Title Act was enacted and 17 years since the Federal Court finding of Native Title on Noongar lands. Yet our people are still waiting for true justice and fair compensation for our losses. Only a fair and just settlement of our claim by the Federal Government can deliver the resources we need for urgent expenditure on breaking the cycles of violence and alcohol abuse; on safe and secure housing; on parenting and mental health support; on better schooling and vocational training; on school attendance and learning support; on on-country led retreat facilities with Elder support; on re-establishing cultural connections and knowledge in our young people; on protecting our cultural sites and buying back land; on developing tourism opportunities; and on educating the broader community on Noongar culture.
We therefore ask the House to direct the Attorney-General to enter into immediate and genuine negotiations with Noongar Elders on a fair and just terms compensation settlement.
from 161 citizens (Petition No. EN4808)
Vaccination
Too many people globally have suffered injuries from the mRNA vaccines, for example, the North Dakota Senate in the US has launched a Bill to ban mRNA vaccines.
We therefore ask the House to Ban mRNA vaccines in Australia, or at the very least introduce a 2 year moratorium so further safety testing can be done.
from 132 citizens (Petition No. EN4810)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

p.span: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

The majority of Australian citizens don't want an indigenous voice to Federal Parliament. The people certainly don't want a referendum which would be a total waste of resources, (considering Australia is headed for a recession & a global credit crunch is highly likely in 2023).
The Fed Govt's credibility is already in tatters over the "safe & effective" vaccines.
We therefore ask the House to Cancel the referendum for a 'indigenous voice to Parliament'. (No one knows what they're voting on anyway as the govt hasn't provided any details or specifics).
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN4819)
Superannuation
Why should the banks make billion dollar profits quarterly in the way of interest rates just to "curb consumer spending" and lower inflation?
Superannuation was introduced in Australia to combat inflation by locking peoples savings away rather then giving hard earned money to the banks.
Its out right robbery.
Compulsory increased savings can be adjustable and it's obviously beneficial to the retiring citizen.
Of all the benefits, the amount of taxes that get spent on the pension would be reduced and that money can be used elsewhere.
Why do the rich have to get richer and the poor get poorer?
Why suppress society, this great country?
We work hard for a wage, why allow the RBA to steal it from us?

Slow consumer spending? Hold onto our money and give us hope of a retirement of quality and self respect, not make us struggle mentally and physically by giving it hard earned money away to the point we lose everything, have to choose between food and electricity.
Its not brain surgery.
We therefore ask the House to lower interest rates and allow inflation to get down by introducing compulsory savings of preferably pre tax salaries and wages, which we could access later in life.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN4822)
Australian Broadcasting Corporation

There is an overwhelming left-wing bias in programming by ABC Australia that does not accurately represent the people of Australia, nor does it demonstrate that ABC Australia complies with its' impartiality requirements under the ABC's Code of Practice. The ABC frequently produces content that favours and promotes particular groups of people such as the LGBTQ trans activists whilst negatively portraying any person of an opposing view, particular those of the Christian Faith. The ABC also promotes material that is atheistic in nature and does not provide alternative views. As the ABC receives tax-payer funding, the ABC should be accountable to all Australians and provide fair and balanced views, which it currently does not.
We therefore ask the House to organise for an independent review into ABC Australia's conduct and systemic bias that is at times, highly offensive and not representative of many Australian people.

We request that appropriate action is taken to organise for an independent, impartial body to collect and review data using statistical analysis concerning ABC's content to determine the extent of the ABC's bias. We also request that appropriate action be taken to prevent ABC Australia from solely producing and advancing left-wing content. We request that quotas, if necessary, are implemented to ensure the above.
from 91 citizens (Petition No. EN4823)
Refugee and Humanitarian Visas

There many Turkish people in Australia whose family are stuck homeless because of the earthquake and are worried about them. The Government should allow Turkish people living in Australia to bring their family members to Australia temporarily.

We therefore ask the House to help and support people in Turkey, officially the Republic of Turkiye, who are homeless and have family in Australia to come to the Australia, like the Ukraine subclass 786 visa.
from 254 citizens (Petition No. EN4824)
National Library of Australia: Trove
Trove is essential for researching all types of family history, as well as all types of historical data. It must be saved. We ask the House to contribute more funds into saving Trove.
We therefore ask the House to contribute more funds into saving Trove.
from 52 citizens (Petition No. EN4825)
Renewable Energy
Call for a parliamentary inquiry into the conduct of the developer in relation to Chalumbin Wind Farm, including the developers:
Refusal to engage in proper consultation with the community.
Deliberately and in a sustained matter misleading the community about the development.
Providing knowingly false and misleading information in the draft Public Environment Report.
In addition, the scope of the inquiry to include:

The cumulative impacts on proposed / future wind farm developments. These developments are targeting high biodiversity areas with threatened species being impacted. The cumulative impacts of these developments are not currently being assessed.
The targeting of vast, high biodiversity areas for wind turbine developments due to:
The size of properties meaning negotiations are confined to small numbers of landholders.
Weak state legislation regarding material change of use and the lack of public input into the process. The impact of state approval on the federal process.
Access to transmission lines and the electricity grid.
The targeting of small communities and the associated social and opportunity costs.
Cultural Heritage.
The refusal of developers to properly engage with communities. The use of so-called 'information sessions' to attempt to tick the box on consultation with no actual consultation taking place.
The difficulties communities face in resources and time frames to respond to proposed developments through the current process.
If foreign-owned companies with a stated aim of exporting Australian 'green energy' is in the national interest and will lead to decreased power process as claimed.
We therefore ask the House to hold an open parliamentary inquiry into these issues, seeking input from those impacted.
from 1,507 citizens (Petition No. EN4826)
Feral Animal Management: Horses

The unjustified persecution of Brumbies lent institutionalized endorsement from sections of government bureaucracies, has become an historical institutionalised prejudice, fuelled by rhetoric, inconclusive research produced by unelected ideological environmental minorities. Brumbies are recognised internationally as an Australian icon, Brumbies have lived symbiotically with native wildlife for over two hundred years. Brumbies contribute to biodiversity, reducing fuel for wildfires, hold a place in Australian cultural history, and tourism. Coins minted, stamps created in their honour. Barbaric unjustified cruelty toward Brumbies that does not conform with national standard operating procedures or community values has been routinely well documented, cruelty non-conforming with national standard operating procedures and best practice. There are now cultural and institutional barriers blocking policy reform on Brumby protection which has become extreme leading to community volatility. Brumbies supported Australian soldiers, Australia's Light Horsemen became legendary, 'Bill the Bastard' one of their bravest steeds. Banjo Patterson wrote The Man From Snowy River acknowledging the bond with Australian Brumbies, Elynne Mitchell recognised the connection in her books, and artists and film makers immortalised Australian Brumbies in film and song. Brumbies are gentle sentient beings, forming strong family bonds, and recognised as descendants of horses contributing to the establishment, protection of this nation.

We therefore ask the House to recognise the Heritage value of Brumbies, to protect that value with introduction of a Commonwealth Heritage Brumby Bill for Legislation, to operate concurrently with State Legislations providing an overarching umbrella of protection for Australia's Heritage Brumbies.
from 3,056 citizens (Petition No. EN4827)
Disability Support Pension
We request amendment to the Social Security (Tables for the Assessment of Work-related Impairment for Disability Support Pension) Determination 2011.
Table 5—Mental Health Function states that a psychiatrist, or clinical psychologist and GP can diagnose a mental health condition.
Nurse Practitioners are masters qualified advanced practices nurse, endorsed by AHPRA. Mental Health Nurse Practitioners specialise in:
- Comprehensive, holistic and biopsychosocial assessment
- Ordering investigations including pathology
- Formally diagnosing mental health conditions as per DSM-V
- Prescribing medications such as antidepressants, antipsychotics and in some states, continuing a psychostimulant prescription, and opioid replacement therapy.
- Psychological therapies including CBT, DBT, Schema Therapy, EMDR...
- Referring to specialists as clinically indicated.
- Liaising and collaborating with the consumer's health care team.
- Writing NDIS, court reports

On 30/04/2018, I wrote a letter to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Dan Tehan MP regarding this, and received a response from Kath Paton (A/g Branch Manager, Families and Pensions) on 30/05/2018. The response stated that an advisory committee was consulted to review the impairment tables, which included representation from RACGP, RANZCP, APS and MHCA among others. I believe Nurse Practitioners were not included in this. The outcome reviewed in 2010-11 was that a high level of diagnostic expertise is required given the diagnosis of a mental health condition.
Mental Health Nurse Practitioners certainly have a high level of diagnostic expertise and should therefore be included in Table 5.
All Nurse Practitioners should be recognised under the legislation as diagnosticians.
We therefore ask the House to propose an urgent change to the legislation.
from 218 citizens (Petition No. EN4834)
First Nations Australians: Retirement

Many Aboriginal people die before reaching retirement age, this is evidenced in the Australian Bureau of Statistics reporting. It is unfair that Aboriginal people are bound by retirement age legislation that does not match current statistics. The ages should be changed to sixty for both men and women. Should Aboriginal people choose to work after this age they should be given an incentive payment lump sum paid into the superannuation.

We therefore ask the House to reduce the retirement age for Aboriginal people in Australia to be in line with the morbidity rates or as asked in the petition above and have an incentive payment for continuing to work after this age.
from 270 citizens (Petition No. EN4835)
Consumer Law
Many purchases are subject to charges which are not presented within the prices listed. Some examples of these are:

Credit card surcharges (which are often either not advertised or are mentioned on small stickers somewhere in the vicinity of the cashier that many customers will not see). These surcharges are sometimes not even avoidable, when retailers are refusing to accept cash.
Public holiday surcharges.
"Handling fee" or similar.

We therefore ask the House to outlaw any additional charges over and above the prices listed for selling of goods or services. The listed price should be the highest amount a customer should ever be expected to pay.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN4838)
Workplace Relations

Employees who are made redundant between the period of November 1st to December 31st face significant challenges. Many companies do not hire so late in the year and defer any recruitment to the next year, making securing new employment difficult leaving many jobless and without income for almost 3 months and leaving them in financial difficulties. In addition, this period of year is often costly, with pre-booked holidays or family gatherings that require significant costs which can lead to increased financial strains. With the downturn of the economy and the increase in no-fault termination of employment, many employees are paying for the financial consequences of irresponsible operations management and planning of many organisations.

We therefore ask the House to provide better worker protections for employees made redundant at no fault of their own from November 1st to December 31st. Better rights can include expanding compensation rights to those who have been with a company for less than 6 months to include 4-6 weeks of pay in lieu. In addition, those who have been with the organisation for more than 6 months are entitled to 2 months of pay in lieu. Those who have been with the organisation for more than 1 year should be entitled to 3 months of pay in lieu. These requests are designed to assist employees in finding financial stability until the recruitment market picks up in January and to ensure organisations are the ones financially responsible for their layoffs.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN4839)
International Students

As stated by NTEU, international student workers are susceptible to exploitation by employers, with underpayment, wage theft, bullying, harassment, and labour trafficking all potential risks. These risks increase when work hours for students are restricted.

When a student arrives in Australia the market situation, inflation, accommodation challenges are at a different level than an year later. Students often find it hard to manage their living costs which does increase by many folds in most cases as the time passes by and then restrictions on work hours make it worse for them to be able to survive and makes it really hard to focus on studies.
Even UNSW, Uni of Adelaide and many other institutes/organizations have recognised that unrestricted work tights have helped both, international students as well as businesses and hence Australia.

Besides all these reasons, in spite of paying three or four fold more tuition fee than domestic students, international students don't have the same work rights as domestic students which is unfair. Due to work hours restrictions students are not employed by most employers who are looking to find someone permanent and students have to settle for odd jobs or labour jobs and cannot work in the domain of their education and skills. To provide equal opportunities to the international students, they should be allowed to work unrestricted hours.
We therefore ask the House to kindly consider removing the restrictions on work rights of international students permanently.
from 7,645 citizens (Petition No. EN4842)
Medicare

The economic well being of Australia is dependant on how much foreign skilled migrants Australia attract per year to assist with the GDP growth and fill a needed annuals skills shortage. Many Australians and residents (about 30% according to ABS statistics 2021) were born overseas. To bring aged parent to Australia the pathways take very long time up to 30 years of processing time, parents from overseas don't get Medicare Coverage for Aged Parents in Australia. This puts financial hardship on Australians citizens from migrants background and Australia foreign residents to pay for Private health insurance that covers their parents whom in many cultures must be looked after by children. Australians from overseas background and migrants pay full tax and medicare levy, they should be able to get medicare service for their parents specially with the long waiting lists of parent visas. Others can argue against wasting tax payers money on foreign parents who are not productive or benefiting the Australian Community, it is worth mentioning that foreigners (migrants under various visas) contribute to the Australian economic wellbeing according to Henry Sherrell is a Policy Analyst for the Migration Council of Australia "Australia's projected population will be 38 million by 2050 and migration will be contributing $1,625 billion (1.6 trillion) to Australia's GDP."

We therefore ask the House to revise the migration and medicare laws to allow medicare services to aged parents who are coming (or in Australia), either on visitor visas, bridging visas or aged parent migration visas.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4843)
Medicare

There is already an enormous pressure put on our public health services, with many seeking out medical help using the emergency department for what usually may not be life threatening causing huge delays etc. We need more GP's to be able to bulk bill, but most surgeries can't afford to anymore. Also those who need mental health help aren't able to access them as much as the rising cost of living is going up so are access to therapies, making them almost unattainable for many.
We need more help and support for those who need the help.
We therefore ask the House to please push for bulk billing increases to match the current inflation rate. To push for more services for those who are in need and the lower income brackets.
from 279 citizens (Petition No. EN4849)

subdebateinfo.title: Universities: Nursing and Midwifery Training Placements

p.span: Universities: Nursing and Midwifery Training Placements

As many are aware the government have recently made changes to support new and incoming nursing and midwifery students to try and reduce the workplace shortages across Australia. They are reducing or clearing the HECS debt and going to financially support new students while on placement which is definitely a move in the right direction.

But what about us, the current students? Those who are passionate about healthcare and struggling to survive, completing a minimum of 800 hours (1600 hours for those completing a double degree) of full time unpaid placement while being expected to maintain our studying. For example for this 12 week period of University my particular cohort is expected to work unpaid for 7 weeks.

Many students cannot afford to even complete placements due to the additional costs of transport, parking (so we don't have to walk kilometres in the dark), the rising cost of living and occasionally accommodation when we are unable to be placed close to our residence.

We, students can already identify where the healthcare system is failing nurses and patients. We are compromising not only our own safety with the ridiculous travel commitments and working hours but also the safety of others including our patients.
You beg for us to join the workforce, say you need us but we burning out, loosing hope and giving up before we even get there.
We therefore ask the House to financially support current nursing and midwifery students while on clinical placement not only future students.
from 3,875 citizens (Petition No. EN4851)
Groovin the Moo

Groovin' the Moo (GTM) is a festival that has existed since 2005 and has sought to bring some of the nation's best musical acts to regional communities. For many years, the Queensland leg was held in Townsville. Disappointingly, this festival has recently lost its regional focus and now half of the legs of the 2023 GTM tour are now in metropolitan centres—Canberra, Adelaide and the Sunshine Coast.

Triple J, alongside the ABC, are national broadcasters and therefore have an obligation to the entirety of the Australian community, including Northern Australia. A "regional festival" that has no leg in Northern Australia and has three steps in metropolitan Australia should not receive support from Triple J or any Government-owned broadcaster.
We therefore ask the House to request the Minister for Communications to:
- Direct Triple J to withdraw sponsorship and funding of Groovin' the Moo, and
- Devise a charter which mandates content in Northern Australia as part of any Triple J or ABC event sponsorship.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN4854)
Environment

As the East Palestine train disaster in Ohio, USA has shown, emergency services weren't knowledgeable about the dangers of dioxins. The emergency services made a major accident now a major environmental disaster worse than a nuclear power station meltdown. The man made burning of vinyl chloride created a dioxin which is the most dangerous known to man. Dioxins are more lethal than nuclear radiation as dioxins don't breakdown over time. Dioxins cause premature death, birth defects, neurological issues etc.
There has to be better regulation of these chemicals & how they're transported. We also need better testing of what dioxins & quantities are in our food supplies & the environment.
We therefore ask the House to Investigate whether Australia needs to setup an independent panel of experts to oversea dioxins in our food chain & environment.
We need all foods tested & results published regularly & publicly.
Also train our emergency services properly how to deal with vinyl choride spills, (ie: never combust otherwise create deadly dioxins).
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4856)
Migration

Due to the unreasonable time taken to queue, process, and consider family visa applications, applicants can legally live and work in Australia on bridging visas for lengthy periods (e.g. in excess of 7 years). This passing of time means that some conditions at the time of application will change and cannot reasonably be expected to remain the same when the application is finally considered (e.g. a child grows up and is no longer deemed a dependent).
During this time, applicants build a home, contribute to society, and establish themselves in Australia, and very often have no remaining resources and connections in the places they left.
The uniting of families in Australia provides significant benefits, and the impact on the well-being of families in Australia cannot be underestimated.
We therefore ask the House to establish a permanent residency pathway for family members who have legally been in Australia on bridging visa for lengthy periods.
from 417 citizens (Petition No. EN4857)
COVID-19: Testing
Antiviral treatments for covid-19 are only effective in the first few days of initial infection. A positive PCR test is currently required to gain access to antivirals.
Therefore by requiring a GP referral to gain access to a PCR test, people miss the window of protection from covid-19 via antivirals.

Currently most people cannot get into a GP for 1-4 weeks. Therefore there is increased health complications and economic costs to treat people who miss out on antiviral treatment. The cost of long covid can cause people to lose the ability to work for life.
We therefore ask the House to reinstate no referral required for PCR tests at pathology or swab collection sites.
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN4859)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Govts are claiming the jabs are 'safe & effective' but govts provide no proof of how many people in Australia are actually unvaccinated.
Without this core data any estimates of jab safety is simply unreliable as the latest ONS data in the UK has demonstrated.
Most independent statisticians in the UK are saying the ONS govt data on jab mortality is useless.
We therefore ask the House to
Ask people their Covid-19 vaccination status in the next census.
We need to know how many jabs people have had at the time of the census to provide the raw data for independent statisticians to interpret the data.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN4862)
Gender and Sexual Orientation
The world is becoming increasingly hostile to transgender, queer and nonbinary presenting individuals.
- Transgender and nonbinary people's rights to live as themselves are being restricted and removed in many countries as a whole or in part.

- This includes the Western democracies which have historically been presumed safe, with The United Kingdom revising their Equality Act to exclude trans people from its protections and more than a dozen American states have enacted or are considering legislation eliminating or criminalizing gender-affirming care, as well as seeking to prosecute Drag Performers and people "impersonating the opposite gender".
Australia needs to step up as a nation and stand for an inclusive, tolerant, and welcoming society for everyone regardless of gender identity or gender expression.

We therefore ask the House to extend to transgender, nonbinary and gender non-conforming people the right to claim asylum in Australia by reason of eliminationist laws in their home countries, whatever country that may be.
from 3,261 citizens (Petition No. EN4863)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

The NDIS Worker Screening Check is designed to ensure that a potential support worker is not a risk to any person with disabilities (PWDs). However, with over 7000 reports of violence and neglect within 1000 support homes, it is simple to conclude that the NDIS worker screening check has little effect on ensuring the safety of PWDs.

By regulating onboarding and psychological evaluations through the NDIS worker screening check, the NDIS and the Australian Government ensure that each support worker is sound of mind, is trained in violence prevention and detection, and understands the needs of PWDs. These improvements will better fulfil the purpose of the screening check.

We therefore ask the House to pressure the NDIS Quality and Safeguards Commission to strengthen their NDIS Worker Screening Check to effectively protect the rights of all half a million Australians under their care.

We request the inclusion of a psychological evaluation and mandatory onboarding process for all NDIS workers. We ask this to ensure that people with disabilities in our communities remain safe and cared for by workers that the necessary tools to provide quality care.
These workers should have the skills to detect and report signs of violence, abuse and neglect within our homes and public spaces, an issue affecting 50% of Australians with a disability.
We, the people, believe these to be the necessary steps in ending the violence and showing our society that we care for people with disabilities and their rights to safety, respect and to justice.
from 43 citizens (Petition No. EN4870)
Medicare

Recently, Medicare rules were changed, so now patients can no longer claim Medicare rebates for telehealth appointments with their General Practitioner unless they have seen their General Practitioner in person in the previous 12 months.
This creates a massive barrier to healthcare for patients who cannot attend their General Practitioner in person due to
a) being housebound due to chronic illness/Disability; and/or
b) isolating at home to avoid catching COVID due to being medically high risk.

It is also a false economy for the Australian Government, as it will contribute to avoidable hospitalisations. It will also contribute to avoidable deteriorations in health that result in premature admissions to nursing homes.

It leaves housebound patients with no choice but to get their medical care through after-hours visits from locum General Practitioners, which cost Medicare far more money than a telehealth consultation with their regular General Practitioner would. Also seeing a different locum General Practitioner every time means there is no continuity of medical care, which results in much worse health outcomes than seeing a regular General Practitioner would.

We therefore ask the House to change the Medicare billing rules so that patients can claim Medicare for telehealth consultations with their General Practitioners as long as they have had a telehealth consultation with that General Practitioner in either 2019, 2020, 2021 or 2022.
from 138 citizens (Petition No. EN4872)
Hospitals: Perinatal Bereavement Suites

My local hospital along with many others around Australia do not have a designated area for bereaved families and their babies. This means we are having to spend our time in the birthing suite & maternity wards surrounded by mothers in labour & hearing the cries of newborns. Appointments are also held in the same area & from my experience sometimes in a lunch room which is not appropriate. All of this only adds more stress and trauma. We are also asking for more support during and after our stay.

There's all these different wards for different reasons but not one for this, that being stillbirth. We should not be expected to give birth right next to someone birthing a live baby. One mother has said her baby was covered up by a blanket before being walked out so he didn't upset other mothers.
There are plenty of families telling their experiences that could have gone differently if a bereavement suite or room was available.
This would mean so much to families going through termination of pregnancy, stillbirth & neonatal deaths.
We therefore ask the House to please understand how important it is for a bereavement suite or room to be included in every hospital in Australia.
from 31,161 citizens (Petition No. EN4873)
Electric Vehicles
To assist in Australia's carbon emission reduction in a manner which includes everyday Australians.

We therefore ask the House to create a financial incentive for people to convert internal combustion engines of existing vehicles to electric motors. Such an incentive would be for an interest free loan for the conversion to be carried out by an Australian based company. Repayments can be made through the immense savings car owners will have of no longer paying for carbon based fuels.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN4880)
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
FIASP Ultra-Fast Acting Insulin is being removed from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) on April 1, 2023 due to a funding disagreement.

FIASP is life-saving for people with Type 1 Diabetes. It is required to be administered multiple times every day—for every meal or snack and to treat high blood sugar. It works faster than any other "fast acting" insulin available which renders alternatives inadequate and outdated.

FIASP makes a significant difference to the quality of life of patients. They are able to live their lives more normally by administering the medication with food, or just after. The alternatives require patients to administer the dose at least 30 minutes prior to eating. That is really difficult when you are out at a restaurant, or at school, or leading a busy, productive life.

More significantly however, FIASP also reduces the risk of complications by reducing the amount of time blood glucose levels remain dangerously high. High blood glucose can lead to significant and life-threatening complications, including stroke, heart attack and death.

We therefore ask the House to urgently overturn the PLAC recommendation to reduce the PBS benefit for FIASP and ensure this vital medication remains available for all Australians with Type 1 Diabetes.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN4886)
Pauga, Mr Talalelei

On 2 July 2020 former Attorney General issued a notice pursuant to s16 of the Extradition Act 1988 on the basis that Talalelei Pauga was an "extraditable person" by virtue of a warrant of arrest issued by Faatasi Puleiata Veatauia on 25 February 2020, and on 16 September 2021 the warrant was withdrawn by the same Faatasi Puleiata Veatauia pursuant to s31(4) of the Criminal Procedure Act 2016 (Samoa) so that Talalelei Pauga is no longer an "extraditable person" within the meaning of the Extradition Act 1988 and yet remains in maximum security prison since August 2020 despite there now being no warrant for his arrest in Samoa
We therefore ask the House to
1. request the Honorable Attorney-General to revoke the s16 notice of 2 July 2020 and take all steps to release Talalelei Pauga from custody

2. refer the circumstances to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Human Rights as to how and why the Extradition Act 1988 can operate to detain a person in Australia in circumstances where there is no longer a warrant for the arrest of the person in the requesting state.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN4889)
Media
Australians' trust in news and journalism is at an all-time low. The damage the Murdoch press has done to the integrity of the fourth estate and public interest journalism cannot be underestimated.
Only a royal commission will be able to expose the true extent of this behaviour and make recommendations to the parliament to ensure it comes to an end.
We therefore ask the House to call a Royal Commission into the Murdoch media empire and the control and influence they have over Australian democracy.
from 45 citizens (Petition No. EN4891)
Broadband

The NBN upgrade works are currently upgrading people who already have access to 10—100Mbit access speeds, to 1000Mbit. Mean while the citizens of Smythesdale and surrounding suburbs are left with fixed wireless at a messily 12Mbit. Their 1000 to our 12!
Country internet access under this scheme is not equitable!

We therefore ask the House to amend the NBN upgrade plans to include Scarsdale, Smythesdale and similar country areas. Also to table a mandate for all Australian ISP's to fully support IPv6 by some specified date.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4892)
Visitor Visas
Australia needs to facilitate entry of sponsored tourist visas for applicants worldwide. Especially Lebanese living in Lebanon to give them the opportunity to see their family and friends
We therefore ask the House to give the chance to lebanese who apply for a sponsored tourist visa to be accepted rather than rejected due to the circumstances in lebanon
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4895)
Disability Support Pension

46% of those with a disability are unable to work due to their debilitating disabilities. 46% solely depend on the Centrelink Disability Support Pension to live. Our financial situation will change drastically when we declare a relationship, we lose our independence and pension. Why do our disabilities have a price tag? We already lack independence and control of our lives. 5.2% of our community have lost their lives to suicide due to feeling like a burden. What is stopping the government funding remaining the same regardless of one's relationship status? DSP base rate is $1026.50 a fortnight. Statistics and data reports say the average annual income is around $55,310 per year after tax. Disability support pension participants earn $24,624 annually. That is a $30,686 gap from the average earnings. If declared in a relationship, participants would be dependent once again on someone else to get by in life while struggling on one income at an average of $55,310 per year. Those statistics is the average for one persons income, how is that supposed to support two? DSP yearly income doesn't even make a dent in the average annual income for Australians. If you take the DSP yearly income and add it to the average annual income of a full time employee after tax you will get $79,310, significantly under the average annual income for a household which would sit around $85,895 after tax.
We therefore ask the House to cut the partner income assesment. We deserve (e)quality of life.
from 10,729 citizens (Petition No. EN4899)
Defence Personnel
A hot war between China & the West is guaranteed, anyone who really understands China knows this.

Given this new reality the Oz govts need to prepare the Oz population by making it mandatory to do 2 years military service for ALL school leavers, (unless there are exceptional personal reasons why they can't).
The other benefits should be kids will learn new skills, maybe a trade, learn some discipline & respect. It'll also slow down & control kids getting into illegal drugs.
As Israel & S.Korea shows, there's substantial real benefits to mandating military service for school leavers. We need to stop the crime problems like Alice Springs has clearly shown.
We therefore ask the House to Investigate making it mandatory for all school leavers to do 2 years military service.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4903)
General Practitioners

With all the advocacy from AMA, RACGP, ACCRM and even our patients the government is still not addressing current problems facing GPs. We need some consolidated, collaborative action as GPs and service users to initiate change. The solutions seem simple and need to be actioned immediately for the following reasons:
To be able to provide affordable and equitable health care to Australians from all walks of life.
To attract more doctors into the GP field of practice.
GPs are integral in keeping the cost of overall healthcare affordable and every dollar spent in primary preventative health care saves thousands down the line.

We therefore ask the House to increase the medicare rebate for GPs, increase financial support to GP practices, change the archaic Medicare laws that are so restrictive with GP billings. For example, patients should be allowed to just pay gap fees and have rest of consult or procedures separately bulk billed so patients in lower socio-economic areas are not required to pay all up front before rebate, allow practices to charge patients reasonable booking fees and/or enrollment fees, allow GP practices to raise revenue by being able to charge for appliances/consumables and specific wound dressings and decrease red-tape to employ GPs from suitable overseas countries.
from 231 citizens (Petition No. EN4906)
Medicare
The Parliamentary Inquiry into breastfeeding in 2007 recommended that the Minister for Health and Ageing give Lactation consultants a Medicare rebate number to support all new mothers to breastfeed.

Optimum infant feeding is a fundamental human right. Australia falls well below Sustainable Development Goal infant nutrition targets. One in three Australian women have a C/section and cannot drive for 6 weeks. The average hospital stay is 5 days. Women who have a C/S have lower breastfeeding rates.
Breastfeeding feeding saves lives, health dollars and is environmentally friendly.

Currently there is a shortage of GP appointments and long emergency department waiting times. A Medicare rebate number would ensure all women can receive expert breastfeeding support when they need it.
We therefore ask the House to implement recommendation 19 of the 2007 Parliamentary Inquiry into breastfeeding and give Lactation consultants a Medicare Provider Number.
from 766 citizens (Petition No. EN4909)
Cybersafety

Online harassment has become a serious problem and one that affects Australian women and girls at higher rates than the global average (Plan International). According to the Australia Institute trolling also has a significant economic cost with a loss of productivity calculated in 2019 to be up to $3.7b.

Despite the fact that online harassment affects 1 in 3 Australians little is being done to address it. Police remain unwilling to lay charges under the criminal code for using a carriage service to menace and harass and increased powers granted to the eSafety Commissioner in 2022 only provide for the most extreme cases of online abuse. In cases of sustained bullying, intimidation and harassment there is no framework in place that protects and compensates victims while holding perpetrators to account.

In 2014 the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) recommended the creation of a Commonwealth Harassment Act to clarify existing criminal offences for harassment and to provide for a new statutory tort of harassment that would enable victims to seek civil remedies. This has been ignored. Similar acts are in place in the UK and NZ and have been effective in both punishing and deterring would-be harassers.

We therefore ask the House to implement the recommendations of the ALRC and in consideration of the National Plan to End Violence Against Women enact a Commonwealth Harassment Act that guarantees the rights of every Australian to participate online free from abuse and harassment providing remedies for victims and accountability for perpetrators.
from 603 citizens (Petition No. EN4913)
Human Rights

The Australian Human Rights Commission has recommended that Australia adopt a national Human Rights Act. Of particular concern, given the human rights abuses Australians faced during the pandemic, the AHRC states in their position paper: "Governments are also required to . . . take measures to prevent, treat and control epidemic and endemic diseases . . . . A government cannot justify its non-compliance with the core obligations set out above. (Page 121)" A Human Rights Act would make it a human right to be tyrannised by the government. It is not the role of government to control the spread of diseases with very low fatality rates, like Covid. It is not a human right to not get sick. Countries with a Bill of Rights or Charter of Rights did not fare better during the pandemic. Canada committed some of the most atrocious human rights abuses, freezing the bank accounts of political opponents. Australia does not need legislation outlining the rights of its citizens. Rights are not something bestowed upon us by the government.
We therefore ask the House to oppose any Human Rights Bill introduced to Parliament.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4914)
Energy
Home batteries (like the Tesla Powerwall) are by far the best way to help households reduce their energy & electric bills, but the problem for most households is they cannot afford the upfront costs.
The States seem to be asleep & incompetent on this critical cost of living issue, so maybe the Federal Govt needs a national plan.
We therefore ask the House to Consider new policies to put batteries in EVERY household in Australia.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN4917)
Parenting Payment
- Childrens needs are ongoing and costly
- Childrens needs don't stop when they turn 8 years of age.
- Children are the future, less access to resources creates undue inequality and can transfer into increased youth crime and health problems
- If single parents cannot afford basic food and shelter, the homelessness epidemic will further increase, refuges are already full.
- Poverty will ingratiate into generations of financial hardship patterns which will negatively impact the economy
- Becoming a single can impact various walks of life and can increase cases of Filicide
- Mental health problems increase and addiction and crime often follow
- The increased cost of living is impacting single parents on 1 income enough, many falling into poverty and homelessness.
We therefore ask the House to increase the Single Parenting payment limit from when the youngest child turns 8 years of age, to when the child turns 16 years of age.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN4919)

subdebateinfo.title: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America

p.span: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America

We have seen in the last 8 years, an increase in medieval viewpoints in the USA, to do with racism, discrimination, the removal of womens reproductive rights, the banning of teaching about different gender identities, the teaching of African American history, the removal of peoples rights to vote in a democracy. I no longer support my Governments alliance with the USA. I do not agree with the influence and corruption that is occurring in my Government due to their USA ties. I don't agree with relaxing any gun laws. I don't agree with removing womens rights. I don't agree with gerrymandering because politicians want more votes since they don't like the younger generations no longer agreeing with their bigotry/racism/discrimination and trying to insert religion into education/medical choices/reproductive choices etc.

We therefore ask the House to propose, discuss and cease our alliance with the United States of America. We are strong enough on our own. We have allies we are more aligned with, such as the UK and Canada. We can still have trade agreements. Not military agreements.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN4926)
Ukraine

More than 200,000 military combatants have died in the War in Ukraine, more than 10,000 Ukrainian civilians have died and 10,000 more are injured. 8 million Ukrainians have fled Ukraine as refugees to Europe. This war has devastated the Ukrainian landscape, cost billions of dollars, caused economic chaos worldwide and could escalate into nuclear war. Australia has been involved in many unnecessary wars in Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan. We now need to be on the side of Peace.

We therefore ask the House to use all means available; including diplomatic and financial means; to discourage continuing conflict and encourage representatives of Ukraine, Russia, North America and European nations to establish a ceasefire along with peace talks to prevent more lives being lost.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN4928)
Telecommunications
Opposing telecommunication companies imposing direct debit on consumers without other alternative payment options being made available
Its not in consumers best interest
We therefore ask the House to introduce legislation preventing telecommunication companies from imposing direct debit only payment options on consumers
from 34 citizens (Petition No. EN4939)
Pakistan

Pakistan is subject to the most brutal fascist regime in the 75 years of its history, and 23.5 million people are hostage to state terror and brutality. Led by the powerful military establishment, the nexus of corrupt generals, politicians, civil bureaucracy, and corporate business groups has taken over the power and resources. The government is becoming increasingly authoritarian, and its policies undermine democratic values and human rights.

People are fighting for their fundamental rights: peaceful protest and gathering. Freedom of speech, media censorship, targeting social media activists and political workers, forced abduction, torture, and extra-judicial killings are the new normal in Pakistan.
We therefore ask the House to probe into the situation and release a statement against this fascism, reflecting the Australian Democratic Values.

For the sake of the people of Pakistan, their fundamental human rights, and liberal democratic values, the global community, especially the Australian government, and members of parliament, DFAT, and the Australian High Commission in Pakistan must act and stand with the people of Pakistan, demanding their right for free and fair elections.
from 376 citizens (Petition No. EN4942)
Taylor, Leading Seaman Ronald (Buck)

Please replace EN4947 with this: A VC medal is awarded to persons who, in the presence of the enemy, display the most conspicuous gallantry; a daring or pre-eminent act of valour or self-sacrifice; or extreme devotion to duty. Yet Ronald Taylor 20863 RAN has NOT been recognised for his ultimate self-sacrifice and extreme devotion to his duty. He has been denied this award. Non-recognition for his bravery is an injustice. We should be ashamed of ourselves if we sit back and accept the decision made. Again, he deserves the highest award for his bravery. I urge that this decision be overturned. One can only be proud of those that paid the ultimate sacrifice. Ronald Taylor however stayed till the end attacking the enemy after the 'Abandon Ship' order was received, the captain of B gun, Leading Seaman Taylor, ordered his two remaining gun's crew to join the rafts. He remained at his gun, determined to fight on by himself; he trained the gun ahead of the leading enemy ship (cont. p88 of HMAS Yarra new edition 2020.) Survivors from the HMAS Yarra stated that he scored a hit on the leading cruiser and that he might have also obtained a hit on a destroyer. At the end of the day, Ronald Taylor did not choose to leave his post. He refused to join his crew and abandon ship and have the chance of survival.
We therefore ask the House to take action.
from 57 citizens (Petition No. EN4948)
Banking and Financial Services
As the bank crisis at SVB & Signature banks clearly show in the US, incompetence of executives & Board Members played a MAJOR role in these banks downfall.
Only one board member of SVB bank actually had banking experience. These banks undertook very risky strategies & failed to hedge against unforeseen risks.
People in the know, knew these problems & withdrew their money causing a traditional bank run.

We therefore ask the House to formulate a new rule/law so executives/Board Members are banned from the financial industry in Australia for life, if they were responsible for a failed bank/financial institution.
As regards a Minister making a decision, it's a yes/no answer.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN4951)
Pakistan

Pakistani elections are being delayed to accommodate the current government. State machinery is being used to inflict pain on pakistani citizens who are trying to express their support for democracy and their politicians. The home of the most popular politician is being tear gassed and rubber bullets are being used against Pakistanis who are trying to express their right of protest. A whole ethnic group numbering in the millions is being racially profiled as terrorists to advance the nefarious designs of the present Pakistani Federal government. Pakistani origin Australian citizens and residents are worried about their families back home and want an end to this cycle of violence perpetuated by the government.

We therefore ask the House to urge the Pakistani government to conduct free and fair elections on time as stipulated by the 1973 constitution without violence or intimidation so that the people can move on from this endless cycle of violence. The Pakistani origin Australians and residents will be eternally grateful.
from 73 citizens (Petition No. EN4954)
Pensions and Benefits
IT IS ABSURED TO INDEXT UNEEMPLOYMENT TWICE A YEAR WHEN THIS MANY UNEMPLOYED REFUSE TO WORK
ALL ASSISTANCES MUST BE TERMINATED NOW!
ALL UNEPLOYED MUST BE MANDATED TO PAY THEIR MADICARE LEVY?
WHY SHOULD WORKERS NOT GET PAYERISES BUT THESE UNEMPLOYED TO BE SUBSIDIZED BY THE MANY WHO REFUSE TO WORK HAS TO STOP!
PRIVATE SECTOR WORKERS ARE THE PEOPLE WHO PAY NOT THE GOVERNEMENT!
PRIVATE SECTOR WORKERS DO NOT TWICE INDEXED PAY RISES!

We therefore ask the House to TO STOP UNEPLOYEMENT BENEFITS TO BE INDEXTED TWICE A YEAR WHEN THE PEOPLE WHO PAY ARE PRIVATE SECTOR WORKERS WHO MANY DO NOT GET THE SAME TWICE A YEAR WAGE INCREASES & ITIS OFFENSIVE TO MANY WHO WORK WHILE MANHY UNEPLOYED REFUSE TO WORK & TIME THESE UNPLOYED TAKE RESPONSIBILITY & PAY THEIR HEALTH CARE THE MEDICARE LEVY & ALL ASSISTANCES MUST BE TERMINATED NOW!
from one citizen (Petition No. EN4958)
Mental Health
1 in 5 Australians suffer from a mental health issue that is 4.8 million people (ABS)
Anxiety, Depression and Substance abuse are the top three mental health issues in Australia (ABS)
Anxiety is the most common mental health disorder in Australia affecting 3.3 million people (ABS)
People with mental health conditions are more than twice as likely to experience homelessness (ABS)
The rate of suicide is steadily increasing over time and is the 15th leading cause of death in Australia (AIHW)
Alcohol induced deaths are the highest they have been in 10 years (ABS)

We therefore ask the House to provide all Australians with free access to psychologists, psychiatrists and other evidence based alternative and complementary therapies that support wellness and mental health. This should include the assessment and diagnosis of mental health conditions.
from 248 citizens (Petition No. EN4960)
Sri Lanka

As you are well aware, Sri Lanka is a country with a rich history of democracy, which has been enshrined in its constitution. However, it has been brought to our attention that the Sri Lankan government has failed to uphold this fundamental tenet of democracy by not holding local government elections that are long overdue.

Recent court decisions have also highlighted the need for the Sri Lankan government to take immediate action to hold these elections. It is therefore imperative that we demand that the Sri Lankan government upholds democracy by holding these elections as soon as possible. Failure to do so will only serve to undermine the democratic principles that Sri Lanka holds dear and could potentially lead to instability in the country.

As you are aware, Australia has been providing financial assistance to Sri Lanka under our development cooperation program. However, the continued pumping of millions of taxpayer dollars into Sri Lanka will be a waste if the expected outcomes of stability and economic recovery are not achieved. It is therefore critical that we take a strong stance and demand that the Sri Lankan government fulfil its obligation to its citizens and the international community by holding local government elections as per the constitution and recent court decisions.

We therefore ask the House to request that the Sri Lankan government uphold democracy by holding local government elections particularly considering the leverage Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has through the Australia's development partnership with Sri Lanka.
from 42 citizens (Petition No. EN4961)
Personal Information and Privacy
People get abused and arrested because laws on film in public is very hazzy
We therefore ask the House to investigate what is lawful to film in public
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4966)
Climate Change
Humanity still has a chance to prevent the worst of climate change's future harms. But doing so requires IMMEDIATE slashing of carbon pollution and fossil fuel use by 2035.

After 6 years of research by over 700 scientists, the IPCC has just released its final Synthesis Report. The report states we are on the brink of global warming exceeding 1.5 degrees Celsius worldwide. Warming over this commences damage to our climate which will be irreversible, threatening environmental systems human life depends on.
The message is clear: no new coal or gas projects.
Cuts to emissions need to be 'deep, rapid, and sustained'. This must happen in a matter of years, not decades.
The current government has approved 30 major coal and gas projects.
Money will come and go. The damage we are doing to this planet is irreversible.
We do not have time for the next election in 2025.

Australia's current climate inaction appears to contradict the public's call for action, with 80% of Australians believe we are already experiencing problems caused by climate change, and 83% supporting the closure of coal-fired power stations.
Australia is the world's third largest exporter of carbon pollution.
As history suggests, such radical government intervention will only occur in response to intense public pressure.
We therefore ask the House to urgently pause the current government's approval of new coal and gas projects in line with Australia's numerous commitments under International Law.
from 39 citizens (Petition No. EN4967)
Cybercrime

Recent high-profile hacking incidents of well-known companies, have caused the security and privacy of millions of Australian customers to be put at risk, following large-scale data breaches. It is unacceptable that consumers should suffer the consequences of these scandalous corporate security failures, if a company cannot reasonably secure their data assets, nor be trusted regarding long-term data retention. Current laws do not go far enough to ensure consumer security and there is little punishment for corporate breaches. This must be rectified. Therefore, we ask that all companies be required to: 1) Securely segment, heavily encrypt, or remove all personal data from their databases when it is no longer required for identification purposes; and 2) When a consumer is no longer a customer of the business, ALL personal data must be removed within a short time frame (21 days) and consumers be notified by the business or company, that this action will occur by a set date. These measures would assist in the future prevention of identity theft, fraud and credit scams, with less personal data being stored for extended periods of time.

We therefore ask the House to pass legislation to implement new laws and regulations to protect customer privacy as a fundamental human right, ensuring companies are held to the highest standard on data management. We urge the House to ensure these measures are adopted and enforced, to better safeguard and protect our personal data from exploitation. Secure Data Retention—Protect Consumers' Personal Information. Thankyou.
from 77 citizens (Petition No. EN4968)
Health Care: Family Planning

If a less intellectually able and person who is in less control of their emotions and impulses aka anyone whose an addict, who has frontal or temporal lobe damage should be granted accessible and free tubal ligation and other hysterectomy without interference from sexist, menopausal women. If a woman is unable to drive ever, is unable to hold down a job that she wants and can't study or survive on her own then she can't be expected to be pregnant on her own. It's her body doing the lifting, it's her body that has to put up with the risks and society doesn't offer enough for what it demands and expects of its women. Until this country is properly run, and functioning at a much higher standard women should be allowed to control their own sex organs. Being a woman and a woman who is of child bearing age causes a lot of distress on the woman and affects her ability to survive and even get educated or employed. Men nowadays are awful and you can't rely on them when you're pregnant or any other time tbh and fair. The laws are in favour of men's OxyContin and not in the best interests of women or children. As a child of single mother I am unable and unwilling to ever be pregnant as I can't drive.
We therefore ask the House to make sterilisation accessible to those who want it.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4969)
National Library of Australia: Trove

This is very important for families when researching family history and it is necessary for Trove to keep going. I have been the secretary of the Broken Hill Family History Group for 39 years. I use this source for information nearly every day as do all of our members. Please consider this request as it would be disaster now to not have this type of information available for people to use.
We therefore as the House to have a long hard think about it before going ahead with any decision please.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. PN0557)
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (16:58): by leave—I present the following 31 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Gold Holdings
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4029 requesting the repatriation of the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) gold holdings held at the Bank of England (BoE).

The RBA has processes in place to ensure that its specified gold bars are maintained appropriately at the BoE, which is the world's second largest gold repository and a globally respected institution. These include:
Inventory reconciliation, which is undertaken periodically and after any movements on the RBA's account.

Audits of the RBA's gold processes, including gold holdings at the BoE. The RBA audited its gold holdings at the BoE most recently in April 2022. This physical verification of the gold bars follows previous audits in 2013 and 2019. No issues have been identified in this audit or previous audits.
Ultimately, operational decisions with respect to Australia's goal reserves are a matter for the RBA Board.
I hope this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Personal Information and Privacy
MyGov
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 regarding Petition EN4090 and 6 February 2023 regarding Petition EN4588 asking the House of Representatives to stop the Digital Identity Legislation and cease attempts to mandate Digital ID via myGov.
The Albanese Government shares the petitioners' passion for ensuring that Australians have their privacy and security protected.
The Australian Government's Digital ID system is a simple, safe and secure way for Australians to choose to verify their identity and prove who they are online.
The Digital ID program has been underway since 2015 and is available to use today with over 10 million Australians already choosing to create a Digital ID through myGovID.

These Digital IDs are being used along with over 1.5 million Australian businesses to access over 125 government services online. Digital ID improves access to services (particularly in remote areas) because it lets people apply for things like Tax File Numbers or Centrelink services entirely online, without travelling sometimes very long distances to a government shopfront.

Digital ID provides an optional way for people to access services without repeatedly providing their identity documents. This reduces the amount of data held by organisations on people using Digital ID, meaning that their data is safer from being hacked.
The Digital ID system (the System) follows a 'privacy by design' approach, with strong privacy and consumer protections. This includes security features which undergo rigorous assessment and testing.
Providers within the System must be accredited under the Trusted Digital Identity Framework and meet strict requirements to protect users' privacy and security, and control against fraud.
This is important to safeguard the system with high privacy, consumer and governance standards and ensure the trust and confidence of Australians.

As the petitioners point out, I also understand that even with these protections in place, not everyone would want a Digital ID. It is important that Australians understand Digital ID is not mandatory. It is completely voluntary and based on consent.
Australians can keep using government services the same way they do now—whether that's online, on the phone or in person at a government shopfront.

The Albanese Government is committed to the success of Digital ID and the protections it offers to access government services online in a secure way, including safeguarding the data and personal information of Australians.

I will continue to consult with the community on these important reforms, and I thank you for bringing these petitions to my attention. I trust that this response provides the signatories assurance in the Government's Digital ID Program.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Finance, Senator Gallagher

Temporary Graduate Visas
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022, enclosing Petition EN4340, with five signatures, concerning the stay period for Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa (TGV) holders who remained in Australia during the COVID-19 pandemic.

As you may be aware, prior to the COVID-19 international travel restrictions which came into effect in March 2020, individuals were generally limited to just one TGV in a lifetime as a primary holder.

The TGV Replacement stream was made available, to take into consideration the number of visa holders who lost time in Australia due to COVID-19 travel restrictions, and in recognition of the important contribution these visa holders make to Australian society.

Furthermore, an additional pathway has been provided for TGV holders who were in Australia throughout the pandemic period and are not eligible for the Replacement stream. These visa holders may be eligible for the COVID-19 Pandemic Event (subclass 408) visa with a two year stay period. This visa aims to support those already contributing to the Australian labour force. Applicants need to meet eligibility criteria, including lodging their application 90 days before their TGV expires, or 28 days after their TGV expires. More information can be located on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/temporary-graduate-485.

In addition, the Government has announced it will increase the duration of stay by two years for TGV, for graduates with select bachelor and higher level degrees. This measure will make Australia's post study offering highly attractive, facilitating longer stays onshore with generous work rights.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4340 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Tigray
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email regarding the petition on the conflict in Tigray, northern Ethiopia.

The Australian Government welcomed the 2 November 2022 peace agreement between the Ethiopian Government and the Tigray People's Liberation Front and continues to encourage all parties to seize this opportunity to build an enduring peace in Ethiopia. During the course of the conflict, Australia regularly voiced concerns over human rights violations, and the impact on humanitarian assistance. We continue to encourage comprehensive human rights investigations leading to justice and accountability, and all parties to work together to build a lasting peace.

The Australian Government is encouraged by the resumption of humanitarian deliveries and of government services in areas impacted by the conflict. We are also monitoring reports of the withdrawal of Eritrean military units from towns in Tigray. Australia has consistently called on Eritrea to cease its involvement in the conflict.

We note the petition requests Australia consider an intake of Tigrayan refugees. Australia's Humanitarian Program intake draws from a range of nationalities, ethnic and religious groups, reflecting the displacement arising from conflict and persecution in many areas of the world. The Program operates flexibly to respond to evolving humanitarian situations and global resettlement needs. It seeks to balance responses to emergency situations, while providing places for other caseloads in need of resettlement across the world, in line with advice from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). A total of 13,750 places in 2022-23 will ensure we can provide permanent resettlement to those most in need, and provide appropriate support for the travel and resettlement of refugees and others requiring Australia's protection.

Any person who believes they meet the requirements for a humanitarian visa and wishes to seek Australia's assistance can make an application. This, of course, includes ethnic Tigrayan Ethiopian nationals. Each application is considered on its individual merit. Priority is given to the most vulnerable applicants who are assessed as refugees by the UNHCR and formally referred to Australia for resettlement, and those proposed by an immediate family member.

Australia is supporting agencies on the ground to deliver lifesaving assistance for the people of Tigray. Since September 2022, we have committed $25 million in funding to help meet the needs of vulnerable people in Ethiopia and neighbouring countries in the Horn of Africa. We have committed more than $232 million in funding to the World Food Programme since 2021-22, to respond to global food insecurity hotspots. The Australian Government will continue to use trusted partners to deliver vital humanitarian support in Ethiopia and elsewhere.

We will also continue to prioritise our non-emergency support for Ethiopia and Eritrea to programs administered by local community organisations, Australian NGOs and multilateral agencies. Australia does not currently have an autonomous sanctions regime on Ethiopia or Eritrea. However, we keep our autonomous sanctions under regular review.
I thank the Petitions Committee for highlighting the situation facing the people of Tigray in Ethiopia and for the requests.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN4491)
Australian Currency
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition 4543 on replacing the Queen's portrait on the $5 banknote with an image of the National War Memorial. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Reserve Bank has decided to update the $5 banknote to feature a new design that honours the culture and history of the First Australians. This new design will replace the portrait of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II. The other side of the $5 banknote will continue to feature the Australian Parliament.
This decision by the Reserve Bank Board follows consultation with the Australian Government, which supports this change.

The Bank will consult with First Australians in designing the $5 banknote. The new banknote will take a number of years to be designed and printed. In the meantime, the current $5 banknote will continue to be issued. It will be able to be used even after the new banknote is issued.
Thank you again for your letter.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Vaccination
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 regarding Petition number EN4610 requesting the House revoke protection for companies responsible for supplying COVID-19 vaccines to the Commonwealth on the grounds that those companies 'lied and covered up' information on the efficacy of mRNA vaccines. Additionally, the petitioners have also requested that persons injured by COVID-19 vaccines be allowed to pursue legal recourse.

There is no scientifically or medically recognised evidence that indicates the vaccines registered in Australia for COVID-19 are not safe and efficacious for the overwhelming majority of individuals. All vaccines that are available for administration under the national roll-out in Australia have been evaluated by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) in accordance with the legislation. Further, decisions made in relation to the roll-out have been supported by advice from the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation.

The Commonwealth acknowledges that, in very rare instances, individuals may experience adverse effects from COVID-19 vaccines. In recognition of those instances, the Commonwealth has established the COVID-19 Claims Compensation Scheme (Scheme). The Scheme provides a mechanism for individuals who have experienced an adverse effect relating to seven clinical conditions identified by the TGA to claim compensation. The Scheme does not require claimants to establish fault.

Alternatively, an individual may decide to pursue litigation against a vaccine manufacturer at their discretion. There is no basis for the view expressed by the petitioners that an individual is 'not free to pursue legal recourse'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Housing
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your referral dated 6 March 2023, concerning the petition calling for a Royal Commission into housing and homelessness in Australia.

I would first like to pass on my gratitude to the organisers and signatories of this petition for taking steps in an effort to improve the lives of the many Australians facing housing insecurity and homelessness. The Albanese Government understands the urgency of addressing these concerns and is committed to working with the states and stakeholders across the housing system to improve housing and homelessness outcomes for Australians.

I recognise the signatories to this petition have called for the establishment of a National Housing Strategy. I am pleased to share that the Government is developing a National Housing and Homelessness Plan (the Plan) to identify the short, medium and long-term steps that can be taken to address housing and homelessness issues in Australia.

The Plan will be developed in collaboration with key stakeholders including state and territory governments, local government, not for profit and civil society organisations, industry bodies, superannuation funds and other experts in housing, finance and urban development.

I note the petition has detailed the need to allow Australians to provide statements about their lived experiences of homelessness and housing insecurity. The Plan will present an opportunity for people to provide statements through an extensive consultation process.
The Plan will build on work of previous inquiries and reviews including:

The Inquiry into Homelessness in Australia conducted by the Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs. The final report is available from the Parliament of Australia's website at: www.aph.gov.au

Inquiry into the contribution of tax and regulation on housing affordability and supply in Australia conducted by the Standing Committee on Tax and Revenue. The final report entitled 'the Australian Dream' is available from the Parliament of Australia's website: www.aph.gov.au

The Productivity Commission's review into the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement. The final report, entitled 'In Need of Repair: The National Housing and Homelessness Agreement' is available from the Commission's website: www.pc.gov.au.

If individuals or organisations would like to receive updates on consultation opportunities and information about the progress of the Plan they can subscribe for updates at www.engage.dss.gov.au/developing-the-national-housing-and- homelessness-plan/.

In addition to the Plan, the Albanese Government is committed to an ambitious housing agenda which will boost the supply of all housing—more social housing, more affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy—to address the cost of housing whether you are buying or renting.
Many parts of the Albanese Government's agenda have already been delivered including:

re-establishing the Housing and Homelessness Ministerial Council (Ministerial Council) to work collaboratively across all levels of government to address housing and homelessness challenges across Australia;

establishing the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee 3 months early, helping regional Australians purchase a home with as little as a 5 per cent deposit and avoiding paying Lenders' Mortgage Insurance;
widening the remit of the National Housing Infrastructure Facility which has unlocked up to $575 million to be spent on delivering social and affordable housing with projects already announced;
establishing the interim National Housing Supply and Affordability Council to provide expert advice to Government on housing supply and affordability; and

striking a National Housing Accord to bring together all levels of government along with investors and the construction sector, alongside $350 million in additional federal funding to support the delivery of social and affordable housing.

The Albanese Government has also introduced legislation to establish the $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund, the largest investment by a Commonwealth government in housing in more than a decade.

The Housing Australia Future Fund will support the delivery of 30,000 new social and affordable homes in the first five years of operation, as well as provide specialist responses to veterans at risk of homelessness, women and children escaping family violence, older women at risk of homelessness and repairs to remote Indigenous housing.

The Albanese Government also provides approximately $1.6 billion per year to the states and territories through the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement to assist states in delivering social housing and homelessness services.
Thank you again for taking the time to share this petition with me. I hope this information has been of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing and Minister for Homelessness, Ms Collins(Petition No. EN4753)
Media
Dear Chair

I refer to the email of 14 February 2022 from the former Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Ken O'Dowd MP, to the former Minister for Communications, the Hon Paul Fletcher MP, regarding Petition EN3540, raising comers about reporting by the ABC and SBS on a range of issues.

Following the May 2022 Federal Election, a new Standing Committee on Petitions was appointed for the 47th Parliament in September 2022. The petition has since been referred to me as the current Minister for Communications. I apologise for the delay in responding.

While the Australian Government provides an overall level of funding to the ABC and SBS, Parliament has guaranteed the broadcasters' content and editorial independence. Under this arrangement, the manner in which the ABC and SBS present their programming is a matter for each broadcaster's Board and executive.

The national broadcasters remain accountable to Parliament through annual reports, corporate plans, financial and performance audits, and in appearances before parliamentary committees. The ABC and SBS Boards are also required to develop codes of practice on programming matters and lodge this code with the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA).

Concerned members of the public may engage with the ABC and SBS by contacting the broadcasters directly. This is the best way to make sure the broadcasters are aware of any concerns and are given the opportunity to respond.

The ABC can be contacted using the information available on its website at www.abc.net.au/contact/contactabc.htm. Complaints about SBS or NITV content can be directed to the SBS using the information on its website at help.sbs.com.au/hc/articles/360002011516.

Complaints about broadcast content can be escalated to the ACMA if audience members are not satisfied with the response they receive from the broadcasters or have not received a response within 60 days. Information about making a complaint to ACMA about the content broadcast on ABC or SBS is on the ACMA's website at www.acma.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Medicare
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the former Treasurer, the Hon Josh Frydenberg, concerning Petition EN3543 on the Medicare levy. As the petition was not addressed by the previous Government, your correspondence has been referred to me for a response.
The Petition proposes removing the Medicare Levy low-income thresholds so that all taxpayers pay the Medicare Levy regardless of their income level.

The Medicare levy low-income thresholds ensure that liability of taxpayers to pay the Medicare Levy reflects their financial capacity to contribute to the total cost of national healthcare. These thresholds are along-standing feature of the tax system.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
